wikipedia_page.main: Anna Katrina Zinkeisen (29 August 1901 – 23 September 1976) (married Heseltine) was a Scottish painter and artist.

response: There was a church in the burgh in the middle Saxon period.  The present church building dates from the 14th century and is a Grade II* listed building. In the north wall is a mural painting by Anna Zinkeisen in memory of her husband Col. Guy Heseltine of c. 1967 showing birds of the Bible.

In 1930, Brahms published a volume of poems for children, The Moon on My Left, illustrated by Anna Zinkeisen. The Times Literary Supplement judged the verses to be in the tradition of A. A. Milne, "but the disciple's gift is too frequently spoiled by her lack of control. She uses too many capital letters, and too many exclamation marks, too many round O's in long chains, and she is too facetious"."Rhyme Stories", The Times Literary Supplement, 20 November 1930, p. 965 The reviewer quoted with approval an extract from one of her poems, a child's thoughts by candlelight:

Doris Zinkeisen was born in Clynder House in Rosneath, Argyll, Scotland.Modern Scottish Women: Painters and Sculptors 1885–1965  Her parents were Welsh-born Clare Bolton-Charles and Victor Zinkeisen, a timber merchant and amateur artist from Glasgow. Her father's family were originally from Bohemia and had been settled in Scotland for two hundred years. She had a younger sister, Anna Zinkeisen, who also became an artist. The family left Scotland and moved to Pinner, near Harrow in 1909. Zinkeisen attended the Harrow School of Art for four years and won a scholarship to the Royal Academy Schools in 1917 together with her sister Anna. During World War I Zinkeisen served in a Voluntary Aid Detachment at a hospital in Northwood, Middlesex.
